content.question: Read the question carefully. You can receive full credit only by directly answering all aspects of the question. You must answer the question in essay form. An outline or bulleted list is not acceptable. (Note: This exam uses the chronological designations B.C.E. (before the common era) and C.E. (common era). These designations correspond to B.C. (before Christ) and A.D. (anno Domini), which are used in some art history resources.) Using two examples of specific visual evidence, explain how this work demonstrates continuity with established artistic traditions. Using two examples of specific visual evidence, explain how this work demonstrates change from earlier artistic traditions. Using two examples of specific contextual evidence, explain why the work deviates from earlier artistic traditions.

An outline or bulleted list is not acceptable. (Note: This exam uses the chronological designations B.C.E. (before the common era) and C.E. (common era). These designations correspond to B.C. (before Christ) and A.D. (anno Domini), which are used in some art history resources.) Using two examples of specific visual evidence, explain how this work demonstrates continuity with established artistic traditions. Using two examples of specific visual evidence, explain how this work demonstrates change from earlier artistic traditions. Using two examples of specific contextual evidence, explain why the work deviates from earlier artistic traditions.

unit.text: 3: Early Europe and Colonial Americas, 200 - 1750 CE

topic.text: 3.1: Cultural Contexts of Early European and Colonial American Art

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Explain why a specific work of art (or group of related works of art) demonstrates continuity and/or change within an artistic tradition, style, or practice.
